review.title: Generating Conceptual Metaphors from Proposition Stores
review.abstract: Contemporary research on computational processing of linguistic metaphors is divided into two main branches: metaphor recognition and metaphor interpretation. We take a different line of research and present an automated method for generating conceptual metaphors from linguistic data. Given the generated conceptual metaphors, we find corresponding linguistic metaphors in corpora. In this paper, we describe our approach and its evaluation using English and Russian data.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: The term conceptual metaphor refers to the understanding of a concept or a conceptual domain in relation to the properties of another (Lakoff and Johnson, 1980; Lakoff, 1987). For example, development can be understood as movement (e.g. economics moves forward, the engine of economics). In other words, a conceptual metaphor consists in mapping the conceptual source domain (e.g. vehicles) properties to a target domain (e.g. economics). For example, an economy develops like a vehicle. In language, conceptual metaphors are expressed through linguistic metaphors, i.e. natural language phrases expressing the implicit representation of two domains.

sections.heading: 10 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: Contemporary research on computational processing of linguistic metaphors is divided into two main strands: metaphor recognition and metaphor interpretation. In this paper, we take a different approach and present an automated method for generating conceptual metaphors from linguistic data. The proposed approach does not rely heavily on manually encoded resources and does not require a commented training set. It provides a mechanism for metaphor recognition in the face of predefined target and source domains (see Section 8). It also enables metaphor interpretation through patterns shared by target and source lexemes (see Tables 3 and 4). All developed tools, generated resources and validation data are freely available to the community as an open source project at http: / / ovchinnikova.me / proj / metaphor.html.me. In the future, we will examine various word aggregation algorithms and their effect on preserved metaphors.
